The term '''Supreme Being''' is often defined simply as "[[God]]",<ref>[http://www.m-w.com/dictionary/supreme+being definition] according to Miriam-Webster on line dictionary.</ref> and it is used with this meaning by theologians of many religious faiths, including, but not limited to, [[Christianity]],<ref>http://www.actsweb.org/articles/article.php?i=1431&d=2&c=2 and http://www.orthodoxresearchinstitute.org/articles/dogmatics/baroudy_god_supreme_being.htm</ref> [[Islam]],<ref>[http://www.muhammadanism.com/Revelation/Sacred_Theology01.htm Revelation - Sacred Theology<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> [[Hinduism]],<ref>[http://www.hindu.com/2003/09/22/stories/2003092200810800.htm The Hindu] Online edition of India's National Newspaper, Monday, Sep 22, 2003</ref> and [[Deism]].<ref>[http://chnm.gmu.edu/revolution/d/436/ website] showing usage by Deists during the French Revolution.</ref> However, the term can also refer to more complex or philosophical interpretations of the divine.
==Use of the term in religious contexts== ===Christianity=== In Christian Theology, the term Supreme Being is used to refer to God.<ref>[http://www.orthodoxresearchinstitute.org/articles/dogmatics/baroudy_god_supreme_being.htm God - the Supreme Being<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Although mostly used specifically as a reference to God the Father, it can be used to refer to Christ or the Christian Trinity of Father, Son and Holy Spirit.<ref>[http://www.actsweb.org/articles/article.php?i=1431&d=2&c=2 The Sense of a Supreme Being<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
===Hinduism=== {{main|Ishvara}} In the [[Shaiva]] tradition of Hinduism, [[Shiva]] is referred to as the "Supreme Being".<ref>http://www.himalayanacademy.com/resources/books/dws/dws_mandala-02.html</ref>
In the [[Vaishnavite]] traditions of Hinduism, the term is applied to [[Vishnu]]/[[Krishna]].<ref name=Delmonico2004>{{cite journal | author = Delmonico, N. | year = 2004 | title = The History Of Indic Monotheism And Modern Chaitanya Vaishnavism | journal = The Hare Krishna Movement: the Postcharismatic Fate of a Religious Transplant | isbn = 9780231122566 | url = http://books.google.com/?id=mBMxPdgrBhoC&pg=PA31&dq=Vaisnava+monotheism | accessdate = 2008-04-12 }}</ref><ref name = "Elkman1986">{{cite book | author = Elkman, S.M. | coauthors = Gosvami, J. | year = 1986 | title = Jiva Gosvamin's Tattvasandarbha: A Study on the Philosophical and Sectarian Development of the Gaudiya Vaisnava Movement | publisher = Motilal Banarsidass Pub | isbn = }}</ref>
[[Para Brahman]] and [[Para-Vasudeva]] also sometimes referred to as the Supreme Being.
===Islam=== Islamic scholars have used the term Supreme Being to refer to [[Allah]], an Arabic name for The God.<ref>[http://www.mb-soft.com/believe/txh/allah.htm Allah, al-llah<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
===Sikhism=== The holy scripture of the Sikhs, [[Sri Guru Granth Sahib]], uses terms that are sometimes translated as "Supreme Being". Sikhs personally use [[Waheguru]], or the term Ek Omkar, meaning One God.
===Deism=== Deists use the term Supreme Being to refer to the Divine (although the Divine is not defined).
